NZ PRYDA BRACING ANCHOR (PBA) Designed to tie timber studs to bottom plates to prevent uplift. FEATURES AND BENEFITS SIMPLE: Ease and speed of installation. Slotted hole on bottom of bracket provides some flexibility in bolt and bracket position installed. FAST: No checking of timber to ensure flush fitting of board. Can be used for fully closed external and internal walls. DURABLE: The PBA is a one-piece anchor for either side of stud and manufactured with 5mm thick galvanised steel. SPECIFICATIONS PRODUCT PBA CODE STEEL G250 THICKNESS 5mm CORROSION Electro-Galvanised to Z275 RESISTANCE Pryda 12G x 35mm Timber FASTENERS Connector Screw, M12 anchor bolt. 3 NZ BRACING ANCHOR DATA SHEET APPLICATION AND SCOPE OF USE Pryda Bracing Anchor are certified when used and installed in accordance with the product datasheet shown connection details. Pryda fasteners approved for the installation form an integral part of the connection and therefore should be used with all Pryda products installation unless otherwise approved by a certified structural Engineer. Only use the product for its intended applications and the selected product material type within the specified environmental condition as outlined in NZS 3604:2011 Table 4.1. (Refer to Durability section for more details). The NZ Bracing Anchor is for fixing timber studs to timber bottom plates to prevent uplift with a capacity of 10.7 kN in accordance with NZS 3604. The NZ Bracing Anchor incorporates a slotted hole for receiving an M12 anchor fixing for the timber bottom plate fixing to a timber or concrete floor in accordance with NZS 3604. The diagram appears to illustrate details for the installation of Pryda Bracing Anchors in a construction context. Here's a technical description based on the typical components and instructions that would be expected in such a datasheet:

1. **Components Shown**:
   - **Bracing Anchors**: Pryda Bracing Anchors intended for structural stability.
   - **Timber Framing**: Indicates the use of timber structural members.
   - **Cladding**: External wall cladding material shown in conjunction with the framing.
   - **Fixings**: M12 anchors or bolts specified for securing the bracing mechanisms.

2. **Key Measurements or Spacings**:
   - Specific minimum edge distances from the cladding and the framing are highlighted, but no exact values can be extracted without visibility of the dimensions noted on the diagram.

3. **Assembly Order or Installation Sequence**:
   - The installation should begin with the alignment of the bracing anchor centrally on the blocking members before securing with M12 fixings. Details suggest a specific sequence for securing cladding followed by bracing to ensure stability and connectivity.

4. **Critical Details**:
   - Minimum edge distance clearly specified between the edge of the framing and the bracing anchors.
   - Overlap considerations for cladding with a note regarding how it should fit over the framing elements.
   - Clear indication of gaps or necessary clearances for proper waterproofing and allowance for movement within the design.

DIAGRAM DESCRIPTION:
1. **Components Shown**: The diagram includes a timber stud, timber bottom plate, bracing anchor (PBA), concrete foundation, and fasteners (screws).

2. **Key Measurements or Spacings**: The dimensions specified include:
   - Timber stud: 90 x 35 mm
   - Timber bottom plate: 90 x 45 mm
   - PBA screw: 12 x 100 mm
   - Minimum edge distance for screws: 25 mm.

3. **Assembly Order or Installation Sequence**: The installation sequence indicated involves:
   - Securing the timber bottom plate to the concrete foundation.
   - Attaching the timber stud to the bottom plate using the bracing anchor (PBA).

4. **Critical Details**: Key features include:
   - Overlap of the bracing anchor on the timber stud and bottom plate for secure fixing.
   - Minimum 25 mm clearance from the edge for screw placement to avoid splitting.
   - Allowance for uplift resistance as part of the bracing system.

5 NZ BRACING ANCHOR DATA SHEET INSTALLATION 1. Identify where PBA is to be located from application details. Ensure PBA fits within the wall frame plane. 2. Present PBA to junction of bottom plate and stud ensuring a snug fit to both surfaces referring to relevant floor installation detail shown in application details to ensure correct placement across face of bottom plate. 3. Mark position of bolt or M12 screw using the PBA as a guide and remove PBA. Ensure the selected anchorage into the supporting member has an equivalent or better capacity to PBA. When connecting to a solid beam, ensure the M12 bolt or screw is central to the beam. For concrete slab connection near edge, minimum concrete edge distance shall be maintained. 4. Drill appropriate size hole for bolt or screw with reference to supplier’s data sheet for correct hole size and use of the fastening. 5. Place the PBA into position and fasten home the screw or bolt to a snug fit, ensuring face of PBA is tight against face of stud. 6. Screw 5 x Pryda 12G x 35mm Pryda Timber Connector screws into the stud flange. 7. Re-check the tightness of the M12 screw or anchor bolt. 8. Finally screw 2 x Pryda 12G x 35mm Timber Connector screws into the bottom plate flange. IMPORTANT Pryda CODEMARK certificate CMNZ10028 certifies Pryda Bracing Anchor with use of NZ Pryda Timber Connector Screws. Other fixing methods are outside the scope of the CODEMARK.

om plate flange. IMPORTANT Pryda CODEMARK certificate CMNZ10028 certifies Pryda Bracing Anchor with use of NZ Pryda Timber Connector Screws. Other fixing methods are outside the scope of the CODEMARK. Installing proprietary anchors correctly, refer to the manufacturer’s mechanical anchoring information guide for specific installation and performance details to ensure that proprietary anchors are installed correctly. When installing anchors, ensure the: • Required slab edge distance is achieved for non-cracked concrete tension– it is possible to blow out the slab edge during installation if the anchor is too close. Anchor capacity may also be reduced due to minimum edge distance. • Correct depth for required embedment depth to achieve capacity rating. • Capacity rating of selected anchor to supporting member has an equivalent or better capacity to PBA. • Hole diameter is suitable for an M12 anchor. • Hole is thoroughly cleaned out after drilling. • Screw is not overtightened – refer to recommended torque settings.

DIAGRAM DESCRIPTION:
### Construction Detail Analysis

1. **Components Shown:**
   - **Bottom Plate:** The primary element, typically a timber or metal profile.
   - **Metal Anchor Fixing:** A specific anchor design that secures the bottom plate to the concrete slab.
   - **Concrete Slab:** The substrate to which the bottom plate is anchored.
   - **Fixings:** Includes bolts or similar hardware used to attach the bottom plate to the anchor.

2. **Key Measurements or Spacings:**
   - **Anchor Size:** 235mm x 50mm x 1.2mm.
   - **Material Thickness:** 1.2mm G300 Z600 galvanised steel.
   - **Maximum Edge Distance:** 100mm from the edge of the bottom plate to the nearest anchor.

3. **Assembly Order or Installation Sequence:**
   - Position the bottom plate on the concrete slab.
   - Drill holes in the concrete for the anchors.
   - Insert the anchors into the drilled holes.
   - Secure the bottom plate to the anchors using appropriate fixings.

4. **Critical Details:**
   - It is critical to maintain a maximum spacing of 450mm between anchors.
   - Ensure that there is a minimum of 10mm clearance between the bottom plate and the ground to prevent moisture absorption.
   - Verify that overlaps between fixing elements are in accordance with standard building practices to ensure structural integrity.

This installation detail follows NZS 3604:2011

Header Block Anchor 0800 88 22 44 A bottom plate tie down for use with concrete header block bases. Features Specifications • Used in the construction of concrete header block Size: 230 x 50 x 1.2mm bases Material: 1.2mm G300 Z600 galvanised steel • Holds down the bottom plate of timber wall frames Product Code: HBA • Eliminates the need to bolt down the bottom plates • Must be fitted at 600mm or less as per Packing: 50 per ctn NZS3604:2011 cl 7.5 - 12.2 Installation Pryda Header Block Anchors are fitted at 600mm centres or less over the outside edge of the header block before the concrete is poured. Once the concrete has hardened, install the wall frames, then lift the exposed top flap of the Pryda Header Block Anchor back far enough to allow the wall frames to be located onto the concrete base. Two Pryda Product Nails (30 x 3.15mm) are required to secure the Pryda Header Block Anchor to the side of the bottom plate and four Pryda Product Nails need to be fitted into the top of the bottom plate or the side of a stud. Should the Pryda Header Block Anchor not line up correctly with a stud then a block must be fitted. A 75 x 4mm concrete nail must also be fitted alongside the Pryda Header Block Anchor and within 70mm from the edge of the concrete block. 14

Jamb Fixa 0800 88 22 44 0800 88 22 44 A no wedge, no jamb face nailing bracket for door/window fixing. 20mm 175mm Features Specifications • Fast and easy to install Sizes: See dimensions above • No wedging required Material: 1.0mm G300 Z275 galvanised • No jamb face nailing required steel. • Fits gauged 100mm or 75mm wide framing • Suitable for use with solid timber or customwood Product Code: JFB100 mouldings. Packing: 150 per carton Recommended No.6 gauge wood screws (not Fixings: supplied) and/or 30 x 3.15mm Pryda Product Nails. Installation Starting with the hinge side of the opening, nail the slots on the top and bottom brackets, on the faces of the wall. The ends of each bracket should be bent tightly around the stud. Plumb the door jamb using the slots for any required adjustment, then fix brackets by nailing the remaining holes. Repeat with jamb on other side of opening, then adjust and fix all remaining brackets in the same way. Before fixing brackets make sure jamb is plumb. Window Fixing: Pryda Jamb Fixa brackets can be used for fixing timber or aluminium windows that have timber reveals. Fixing details are as per door jamb installation. 15

For higher design loads bend strap ends under Windstrap has a max. design capacity for wind uplift as follows: 11.6kN for J4 and J5 support member and nail with at least 2 nails. * Require 70mm or 90mm deep top plate. ** With strap wrapped under support member. 37

“Z” and “U” Nails 0800 88 22 44 A cost effective fixing for holding down purlins, top plates and trusses. Specifications Sizes 100mm long/40mm over spikes (at 85° to leg) Material 5mm diameter mild steel manufacturing wire galvanised or stainless steel. Product Code & Packing ZL, ZR, ZU 500 Fabricator Pack MPZL. MPZR, MPZU 100 Merchant Pack MPZL/S, MPZR/S, 100 Stainless Steel MPZU/S Features The “Z” Nail is a cost effective means of holding down purlins to rafters, rafter and joists to plates, joists to beams, etc. “Z” Nails are self nailing and easy to apply with the 85° angle of the nail to the shaft enabling the nails to draw the timbers to each other. * “Z” and “U” Nails fixed in subfloor framing applications must be stainless steel when fixed within 600mm from the ground, (refer Table 4.1 NZS3604:2011). chunk_id: NZ Pryda Connectors Tie-downs Design Guide_p2_c0
source: NZ Pryda Connectors Tie-downs Design Guide
content: GENERAL PRYDA BUILDING GUIDE OVERVIEW Pryda has developed this guide to accommodate New Zealand building practices. It is important that designers, engineers, builders, inspectors and building authorities are familiar with the benefits and critical requirements of the system. Pryda timber connectors, trusses and beams comply with the New Zealand Building Code, Section B1 Structure and B2 Durability, having been designed in accordance with sound and widely accepted engineering principles to comply with NZS3604:2011. The capacities reported in this publication are limit state design capacities and not characteristic strengths thereby allowing direct comparison with design reactions reported in Pryda design software and Pryda design reports. This document supersedes and replaces all the previous publications of Builder's Guide. For further design advice or engineering support regarding the Pryda products discussed in this publication please phone us at 0800 88 22 44 or visit our website - www.pryda.co.nz. The Pryda Design Guide features a Building Consent Documentation Reference for many connection details. This is aimed to encourage designers to align details in the building consent documentation with useful information for easy reference for builders and building officials at the time of inspection. The process is illustrated on the following page. It should be recognised that this is not a requirement, and fabricators may choose to present information in various formats.

chunk_id: NZ Pryda Connectors Tie-downs Design Guide_p2_c1
source: NZ Pryda Connectors Tie-downs Design Guide
content: the time of inspection. The process is illustrated on the following page. It should be recognised that this is not a requirement, and fabricators may choose to present information in various formats. The Building Consent Documentation Reference should not be confused with the Pryda product code. The Company Pryda New Zealand is an autonomous division of USA-based Illinois Tool Works Inc. a Fortune 200 diversified manufacturing company with almost 100 years of history. Other successful ITW brands include Paslode, ITW Proline, Ramset and Reid Construction Systems. Pryda also gains valuable benefits in product, fabrication machinery and software development from its association with other ITW software and truss connector suppliers from around the world. Who is Pryda? Pryda was born in Napier, New Zealand in 1964. Pryda has remained an integral part of the building industry in New Zealand for over 50 years, particularly in timber truss and frame solutions with the development of a diverse range of timber connectors and structural brackets. Today Pryda remains a trusted New Zealand brand on building sites, in trade stores and in offices of architects, engineers and designers. Pryda utilises world-class technology to provide a total system package to its licensed truss and frame plants, including fully integrated software and production systems, access to world leading manufacturing equipment and the highest levels of technical support.

chunk_id: NZ Pryda Connectors Tie-downs Design Guide_p2_c2
source: NZ Pryda Connectors Tie-downs Design Guide
content: package to its licensed truss and frame plants, including fully integrated software and production systems, access to world leading manufacturing equipment and the highest levels of technical support. Our Philosophy Pryda develops solutions to common construction challenges on the philosophy, "safer, faster, smarter, easier". Pryda’s philosophy is a unique method of looking at the total business needs of its licensed truss and frame fabricators and providing cost effective solutions that not only meet current requirements but also identify and satisfy long term goals . PRYDA DESIGN GUIDE MARCH 2024 V1.1

source: NZ Pryda Connectors Tie-downs Design Guide
content: GENERAL When producing an 'As Built' truss layout and final truss detailing for supply, it is expected that a fabricator shall give consideration to any 'Buildable' truss layout that has been consented by a BCA. The fabricator shall consider any structural implications that may result from a different layout to that consented and if any changes are to be made then these shall be communicated to the customer to pass on to their design team for consideration and approval before proceeding with supply. It is not expected that fabricators should have to follow exactly a consented layout, particularly when a competitive party may have provided it. However, a fabricator will have to produce an 'As Built' truss layout as per 2.3.1. This two stage process is reflected in section 7.5 of the guidance document "Guide to applying for a building consent" published by the Department of Building and Housing. Acknowledgement and support for the COP Section 2 – Truss Documentation is also outlined in the publication from DBH Codewords issue 044. Both publications are available online at www.dbh.govt.nz. While it is expected that the documentation is going to be provided to assist a BCA in the consent or CCC process it should be noted that the contractual relationship is between a fabricator and its customer and that the responsibility to provide this information to a BCA rests with the applicant for a building consent. Notes: 1.

content: d that the contractual relationship is between a fabricator and its customer and that the responsibility to provide this information to a BCA rests with the applicant for a building consent. Notes: 1. An accredited fabricator is a company that has a formal agreement with a nail-plate manufacturer to use their products in the manufacture of trusses. The nail-plate manufacturer in turn licenses the fabricator to use specific design software supplied and underwritten by the nail-plate manufacturer. 2. A design lead refers to the architect or draftsperson responsible for the overall design of the building. PRYDA DESIGN GUIDE MARCH 2024 V1.1

content: GENERAL - TIMBER CONNECTORS GUIDE PRODUCER STATEMENT PRYDA TIMBER CONNECTORS August 2024 This Producer Statement is issued by Pryda NZ to cover the use, installation, and durability of Pryda Timber Connectors for both structural application and durability as required by the New Zealand Building Code clauses B1 & B2, respectively. Description The Pryda timber connectors are manufactured from either Z275 or Z600 galvanised coil. Some brackets are also available in hot dipped galvanised or stainless steel for use in certain exposed and covered situations. Application Pryda timber connectors are designed for specific connections of timber to timber, primarily, as well as masonry, concrete, and steel. Please contact Pryda should you require assistance relating to these connectors. Installation Pryda timber connectors should be installed without damage to the finished surfaces. Storage prior to use to be in dry moisture free conditions that would not affect the future durability of the product. Design Capacity As timber grades vary the design capacity is derived using the methods in NZS AS1720.2022 and is mostly dependent on the shear values of the nails, screws, and bolts in timber. Most commonly used Timber Connectors have published limit state design strengths published in our literature.

chunk_id: NZ Pryda Connectors Tie-downs Design Guide_p7_c1
source: NZ Pryda Connectors Tie-downs Design Guide
content: 022 and is mostly dependent on the shear values of the nails, screws, and bolts in timber. Most commonly used Timber Connectors have published limit state design strengths published in our literature. Durability The durability of Pryda timber connectors is in accordance with the acceptable solutions contained in Table 4.1 and Table 4.2 of NZS3604:2011 to achieve a 50 year life expectancy for the connectors where applicable. Alternative solutions and direct applications are to be found elsewhere in this publication. 8 41 Poland Rd, Glenfield, 0629 PO Box 100303, North Shore 0757, Auckland. Tel: 0800 88 22 44 Email: info@prydaanz.com PRYDA DESIGN GUIDE MARCH 2024 V1.1

content: GENERAL - STRUCTURAL BRACKETS GUIDE PRODUCER STATEMENT STRUCTURAL BRACKETS Pryda Structural Brackets August 2024 This Producer Statement is issued by Pryda NZ to cover the use, installation, and durability of Pryda Structural Brackets for both structural application and durability as required by the New Zealand Building Code clauses B1 & B2, respectively. Description Pryda Structural Brackets are fabricated from flat bar steel. They are mostly available in hot dipped galvanised finish with a selection also available in stainless steel for use as an architectural feature or in certain exposed and covered situations as covered in NZS3604:2011. The zinc coating is applied in accordance with AS/NZS 4680:2006. The remaining Pryda Structural Brackets are finished in electro galvanised. Application Pryda Structural Brackets are designed to connect timber to masonry, concrete, and steel. The brackets are designed for specific connections of timber to other materials. Please contact Pryda technical service should you require assistance with your intended application. Installation The Pryda Structural Brackets should be installed without damage to the finished surfaces. Storage prior to use to be in dry moisture free conditions that would not affect the durability of the product. Characteristic Strength When used with timber, the characteristic strength is derived by the verification method in accordance with the NZBC standard NZS3603:1993.

chunk_id: NZ Pryda Connectors Tie-downs Design Guide_p8_c1
source: NZ Pryda Connectors Tie-downs Design Guide
content: ffect the durability of the product. Characteristic Strength When used with timber, the characteristic strength is derived by the verification method in accordance with the NZBC standard NZS3603:1993. The withdrawal strength of the bracket varies with the type of substrate it is installed in, hence the limit state design capacities shall be determined by the design engineer taking into consideration the above point. Durability The durability of the Pryda Structural Brackets is more than the acceptable solutions contained in Table 4.1 of NZS3604:2011 in order to achieve a 50-year life expectancy for the brackets. Pryda Structural Brackets are hot-dipped galvanised to a level equal to or exceeding 500g/m2. Depending on the environmental conditions and exposure to mar ine17 c onditions, the surface of the stainless-steel brackets can be affected by tea staining. However, tea staining does not affect the structural integrity of the fitting. Pryda Ceiling and Purlin Hangers are certified when used and installed in accordance with the product datasheet shown connection details. Pryda fasteners approved for the installation form an integral part of the connection and therefore should be used with all Pryda products installation unless otherwise approved by a certified structural Engineer.

content: 4 NZ CEILING AND PURLIN HANGER DATA SHEET INSTALLATION FOR CEILING JOIST CROSSING PERPENDICULAR TO BEAM CONNECTION STEP 1 • Ensure the crossing members are plumb and crossing perpendicular to each other. Position the short leg of the Ceiling and Purlin Hanger to the supported member (ceiling joist), making sure the hanger leg is laying flat on the timber face. • The long leg of the Ceiling and Purlin Hanger should also lay flat to the supporting member timber face. • Fix each leg with the same number of nails according to the capacity table. 3 x Pryda 35 x 3.15mm Timber Connector Nails option shown, fixed to each leg. STEP 2A • The Ceiling and Purlin Hangers are to be installed in PAIRS at each support. • Avoid positioning the hanger where nails are too close to the timber edge. Timber at the connection point must be free from any timber defects such as knots, wanes, and splits. • Left Hand (LH) and Right Hand (RH) shown. 3. **Assembly Order/Installation Sequence**: 
   - Step 1: Ensure crossing members are plumb and perpendicular to each other.
   - Step 2A: Position purlin hangers correctly on the timber beam, ensuring alignment.

4. **Critical Details**: 
   - Key details include ensuring the crossing members meet at right angles.
   - No explicit gaps or overlaps are provided, but the need for correct alignment and fixing is stressed.
   - Minimum clearances or fastener specifications are not detailed in the visible information.

content: NZ CONCEALED PURLIN CLEATS Strong and rigid connection frequently used to connect trusses/rafters to beams and wall plates. FEATURES AND BENEFITS SIMPLE: Can also be used to connect wall plates to studs. FAST: Can be fixed with nails or screws. DURABLE: 2mm G300 Z275 Galvanised Steel or Stainless Steel 304. SPECIFICATIONS PRODUCT NPPC4, NPPC6, NPPC8, NPPC4/S, CODE NPPC6/S, NPPC8/S STEEL G300 or Stainless Steel 304 THICKNESS 2mm and 1.5mm for Stainless Steel CORROSION Z275 or Stainless Steel 304 RESISTANCE Pryda 12G x 35mm Timber C onnector Screws. FASTENERS Pryda 35 x 3.15mm Timber REQUIRED C onnector Nails. 14G x 75mm Type 17 Hex Head Screws. NPPC8 HEIGHT 85mm NPPC8/ S WIDTH 40mm,60mm,80mm DEPTH 30mm At the time of print, this product is NOT subject to any kno wn warnings and bans found in Building Act 2004. *All dimensions shown are in “mm.” Pryda.com.au, Pryda.co.nz DECEMBER 2023 - V1.03 CHECK PRYDA REGION WEBSITE FOR MOST CURRENT VERSION For more information call 1300 657 052 (Australia), 0800 88 22 44 (New Zealand) or email info@pryda.com.au

content: 3 DURABILITY The following table provides an easy guide when selecting a Pryda product corrosion protection finish that will meet and exceeds NZS 3604:2011 Table 4.1. ZONE LOCATION Environment Product Pryda Zinc Coated All Zones Fully enclosed walls, floors, and roof spaces Closed Products Z275 Vented 7000mm2/m2 or Pryda Stainless Steel 304 Sheltered All subfloor fastenings LESS Products (3) more than 600mm above the ground Vented MORE than Pryda Stainless Steel 304 Exposed 7000mm2/m2 Products (3) All subfloor fastenings Zones B and Pryda Stainless Steel 304 within 600mm of the Sheltered and Exposed C Products (3) ground Pryda Stainless Steel 304 Sheltered Products (3) All other structural fixings Pryda Stainless Steel 304 Exposed Products (3) Pryda Stainless Steel 304 Zone D All structural fixings Sheltered and Exposed Products (3) Notes: 1.All Pryda galvanised products comply with NZS3604:2011 Table 4.2. 2.Refer to NZS3604:2011 for all environment definitions. 3.Routine inspection and cleaning using soap and fresh warm water is an integral part of the ongoing care and maintenance of stainless steel to preserve its appearance. STORAGE AND HANDLING Prior to use, the Pryda products shall be stored in a weatherproof environment and protected from moisture. Care must be taken to avoid any damage to the surface of the product protective galvanised coating and profile that may impact the performance.

chunk_id: NZ Pryda Connectors Tie-downs Design Guide_p20_c1
source: NZ Pryda Connectors Tie-downs Design Guide
content: a weatherproof environment and protected from moisture. Care must be taken to avoid any damage to the surface of the product protective galvanised coating and profile that may impact the performance. COMPLIES WITH THE FOLLOWING PROVISIONS OF THE NEW ZEALAND BUILDING CODE (NZBC) Clause B1 STRUCTURE: Performance B1.3.1, B1.3.2 and B1.3.4. Loads arising from self-weight, imposed gravity loads arising from use, earthquake, snow, and wind. (i.e., B1.3.3 (a), (b), (f), (g), and (h)). Only some may apply for a specific use of the component. Clause B2 DURABILITY: Performance B2.3.1 (a) not less than 50 years and B2.3.2. Clause F2 HAZARDOUS BUILDING MATERIALS: Performance F2.3.1. APPLICATION AND SCOPE OF USE Pryda Concealed Purlin Cleats (NPP) are certified when used and installed in accordance with the product datasheet connection details. Pryda fasteners approved for the installation form an integral part of the connection and therefore should be used with all Pryda products installation unless otherwise approved by a certified structural Engineer. Only use the product for its intended applications and the selected product material type within the specified environmental condition as outlined in NZS 3604:2011 Table 4.1. (Refer to Durability section for more details). Fastener material type shall match the selected Pryda product. i.e., Galvanised fasteners with galvanised products, and stainless steel fasteners with stainless steel products.

content:
DIAGRAM DESCRIPTION:
### Technical Analysis of the Construction Detail Diagram

1. **Components Shown:**
   - **Wall Plates:** Double 45mm wall plates depicted.
   - **Fixings:** Two types of fasteners are shown:
     - 14G x 75mm Type 17 Hex Head Screws (galvanised or stainless steel).
     - Pryda 35 x 3.15mm Timber Connector Nails (for the long flange option).
   - **Timber Connector Systems:** Illustrations of connector systems (e.g., Timber Connector Screws, JDS types).

2. **Key Measurements or Spacings:**
   - Wall plates are specified at 45mm width.
   - Screws are 75mm in length with a gauge of 14.
   - Connector nails are 35mm in length and 3.15mm in diameter.

3. **Assembly Order or Installation Sequence:**
   - Start with fixing the double 45mm wall plates using the specified screws.
   - For the long flange option, insert the Pryda connector nails as per specified alignment.

4. **Critical Details:**
   - Ensure proper overlap of connectors if applicable, to provide structural integrity.
   - Minimum clearances for screws or nails need to be maintained to avoid timber splitting.
   - Reference to correct installation orientations is implied (not overtly detailed).

This concise description reflects the technical aspects of the installation detail as per NZ/AU construction practices.

Beam A (Supporting Beam) and Beam B (Supported Beam) must be a minimum 120mm deep to achieve above screw capacities. 2. NPPC8 must be used in PAIRS. 3. Supported joist must be supported on both ends. Connection is not suitable for cantilever support. 4. Brackets supports variable widths. The designer should limit width to prevent eccentric loading on the bracket. 5. Design capacities applies for dry (maximum moisture content of 18%) Radiata Pine and Douglas Fir timber grade SG8 and for timber which meets JD5 timber as defined in AS/NZS 1720 for both supporting and supported beam. 6. Multiple Laminated Supporting Beams: Fasteners with longer lengths are required when NPPC8 brackets are fixed into a multiple laminated supporting beam. For double 45mm laminates, use 14G x 75mm Type 17 Hex Head long screws. Alternatively, for double or triple laminated supporting beams, additional fixings may be provided at hanger locations to laminate plies. Seek advice from the consulting project Engineer.

chunk_id: NZ Pryda Connectors Tie-downs Design Guide_p24_diagram
source: NZ Pryda Connectors Tie-downs Design Guide
content:
DIAGRAM DESCRIPTION:
1. **Components Shown**:
   - NPPC8 brackets (joist/rafter support)
   - Supporting beams (A and B)
   - Screws for fastening the brackets
   - Timber framing (indicated but not explicitly detailed)

2. **Key Measurements or Spacings**:
   - The minimum depth of the supporting beam (A) must be 120mm.
   - Bracket offset to the opposing supporting beam by 5mm.
   - Load capacities specified for pairs of brackets (1.35 kN, 1.5 kN, 2.4 kN).

3. **Assembly Order or Installation Sequence**:
   - Locate the NPPC8 bracket on supporting beam A.
   - Ensure a 5mm offset when placing the bracket on supporting beam B to avoid screw clashing.
   - Use two NPPC8 brackets in pairs for adequate support.

4. **Critical Details**:
   - Ensure that the brackets are installed with an overlap on the supporting beams.
   - Maintain the specified gaps and clearances to avoid structural conflicts.
   - Attention to screw placement to prevent clashing during installation is critical for proper assembly.

Page context: 7 PAIR OF NPPC8 AS JOIST / RAFTER SUPPORT Locate bracket Offset opposing Supporting Beam, A central to beam bracket by 5mm to depth. avoid screw clashing. Supported Beam, B NPPC8 ALWAYS USED IN PAIRS

1. **Components Shown**:
   - Cyclone Straps: Used for securing trusses to the top plates.
   - Trusses: Framing elements that support the roof structure.
   - Top Plate: Horizontal framing member at the top of wall studs.
   - Timber Connector Nails: Fixings used to secure the straps to the trusses.

2. **Key Measurements or Spacings**:
   - Specific measurements for the Cyclone Strap or truss dimensions are not visible in the diagram.

3. **Assembly Order or Installation Sequence**:
   - Step 1: Position the center of the Cyclone Strap over the truss and bend each side down simultaneously.
   - Step 2: Install timber connector nails into each leg of the Cyclone Strap.

4. **Critical Details**:
   - Ensuring the Cyclone Strap is centered over the truss before bending is crucial for effective load distribution.
   - Attention to leg lengths is emphasized, ensuring they are of equal length for proper installation.
   - The instruction allows for the leg folding direction, indicating flexibility in installation but maintaining stability.

content: 7 NZ CYCLONE STRAPS DATA SHEET INSTALLATION OF CYCLONE STRAPS FOR TRUSS TIE DOWN TO BEAM/LINTEL Fixing to a beam or lintel is the same as above however instead of wrapping under the top plate, the cyclone strap legs are fastened to the face of the beam as shown below. Note this is not as strong a connection as wrapping under the top plate and the number of nails into the face of the beam will dictate the capacity as shown in the design capacity table. 2 nails to each face of truss. 2 to 6 nails on beam/lintel per leg. See table for capacities for each nail group. FASTENING CYCLONE STRAPS BUILD WITH CONFIDENCE Where possible, hand nailing with Pryda Timber Connector nails is always preferred, why? • Pryda Timber Connector Nails are forged in one piece, unlike clouts that are two pieces soldered together, meaning the head can pop off. • Pryda Nails are the correct diameter, ensuring a tight fit in prepunched holes = a stronger connection. • Design values and testing have all been conducted using Pryda Timber Connector Nails. • Hand hammered nails ensure correct nail positioning and drive depth (not driven too shallow or too deep). PRYDA CODEMARK CERTIFICATE CMNZ10029 CERTIFIES PRYDA CYCLONE STRAP WITH USE OF NZ PRYDA TIMBER CONNECTOR NAILS. OTHER FIXING METHODS ARE OUTSIDE THE SCOPE OF THE CODEMARK. Paslode's PPN-Master (Positive Placement Nailer) replicates the accuracy of hand nailing by using a probing tip to fire nails through holes in the connector.

chunk_id: NZ Pryda Connectors Tie-downs Design Guide_p32_c1
source: NZ Pryda Connectors Tie-downs Design Guide
content: ODS ARE OUTSIDE THE SCOPE OF THE CODEMARK. Paslode's PPN-Master (Positive Placement Nailer) replicates the accuracy of hand nailing by using a probing tip to fire nails through holes in the connector. Pryda supports the use of the PPN-Master for these products. Unlike traditional nailing tools, no design capacity reduction is required when using the PPN-Master. USING PASLODE MACHINE DRIVEN NAILS 32 x 2.3 mm Duo-Fast C SHEG (i.e.: screw hardened electro galvanized) machine driven nails (code D40810) or equivalent may be used instead of the specified 35 x 3.15 mm Pryda Timber Connector Nails to fix selected Pryda connectors provided that the following requirements are strictly adhered to: • Design capacities shall be reduced by 20% using the same number of nails as specified for the connectors and • Nails shall be driven at nail spacings and edge distances closely following the selected Cyclone Strap hole pattern. content: PRODUCT DATA SHEET NZ EZI STUD TIES Stud ties connect top and bottom plates to studs or lintels to resist wind uplift. FEATURES AND BENEFITS EASY: A quick and effective connector between studs and wall plates or lintels. FAST: Built-in Claw-nails remove the reliant on the position of top plate fixing nails to achieve desired strength. DURABLE: G300 Z275 Steel with Pryda proprietary Claw-nails for superior holding strength. SPECIFICATIONS PRODUCT SST CODE STEEL G300 THICKNESS 0.95mm CORROSION Z275 RESISTANCE FASTENER Preformed Claw nails PRODUCT 186 x 66 x 30mm DIMENSION The Pryda Ezi Stud Tie - SST has been designed to exceed the requirement of table 8.18 NZ3604:2011 – “Fixing of top plate of wall to supporting members such as studs and lintels at 600mm centers”. At the time of print, this product is NOT subject to any known warnings and bans found in Building Act 2004. *All dimensions shown are in “mm.” Pryda.com.au, Pryda.co.nz DECEMBER 2023 - V1.02 CHECK PRYDA REGION WEBSITE FOR MOST CURRENT VERSION F or more information call 1300 657 052 (Australia), 0800 88 22 44 (New Zealand) or email info@pryda.com.au

content: 3 NZ EZI STUD TIES DATA SHEET STORAGE AND HANDLING Prior to use, the Pryda products shall be stored in a weatherproof environment and protected from moisture. Care must be taken to avoid any damage to the surface of the product protective galvanised coating and profile that may impact the performance. COMPLIES WITH THE FOLLOWING PROVISIONS OF THE NEW ZEALAND BUILDING CODE (NZBC) Clause B1 STRUCTURE: Performance B1.3.1, B1.3.2 and B1.3.4. Loads arising from self-weight, imposed gravity loads arising from use, earthquake, snow, and wind. (i.e., B1.3.3 (a), (b), (f), (g), and (h)). Only some may apply for a specific use of the component. Clause B2 DURABILITY: Performance B2.3.1 (a) not less than 50 years and B2.3.2. Clause F2 HAZARDOUS BUILDING MATERIALS: Performance F2.3.1. APPLICATIONS AND SCOPE OF USE The Pryda Ezi Stud Tie is an alternative solution to the fixing type B in Table 8.18 in NZ3604:2011. The Pryda Ezi Stud Tie exceeds the required capacity without relying on the additional 0.7kN contribution of the 2/90 x 3.15mm nails, top plate to stud. Pryda Ezi Stud Tie is certified when used and installed in accordance with the product datasheet shown connection details. Pryda fasteners approved for the installation form an integral part of the connection and therefore should be used with all Pryda products installation unless otherwise approved by a certified structural Engineer.

chunk_id: NZ Pryda Connectors Tie-downs Design Guide_p36_c1
source: NZ Pryda Connectors Tie-downs Design Guide
content: rs approved for the installation form an integral part of the connection and therefore should be used with all Pryda products installation unless otherwise approved by a certified structural Engineer. Only use the product for its intended applications and the selected product material type within the specified environmental condition as outlined in NZS 3604:2011 Table 4.1. (Refer to Durability section for more details). INSTALLATION EZI STUD TIE STEP 1 STEP 2 • Locate the Ezi Stud Tie on the external corner of the • Fasten the top of the Ezi Stud Tie into the top plate. wall plate. In a similar manner, while holding the Ezi stud tie firmly against top plate corner, systematically hammer the claw- • Ensure Ezi Stud Tie is centrally located on the stud. nails from inner clusters to outer claw-nail clusters. Avoid While holding the tie in place at corner, using excessive force and ensure Ezi stud tie is lying flat systematically hammer in the claw-nail, starting on both stud and top plate surfaces. from inner nail cluster to outer. Evenly hammer in all the claw-nails into stud. content: PRODUCT DATA SHEET NZ MULTIGRIPS Multi-purpose metal connectors for timber construction. FEATURES AND BENEFITS SIMPLE: Each of the tabs can bent in or out to 90° or other angles to suit the application. FAST: Suitable for high load applications such as a tie-down connector. Along with being used as a strong tie-down connection, can also be used in numerous right-angle connection applications. DURABLE: 1mm thick G300 Z275 or Stainless Steel 304. SPECIFICATIONS PRODUCT MPMG, MG/S, MPMGL CODE STEEL G300 THICKNESS 1mm CORROSION Z275 or Stainless Steel 304 RESISTANCE Pryda 35 x 3.15mm Timber Connector Nails OR Pryda 12G x 35mm Timber Connector FASTENERS Screws – Painted Red Head REQUIRED Ensure the corrosion resistance of the fastener matches the product, i.e., galvanised nails for a galvanised bracket or stainless nails for a stainless bracket HEIGHT 100mm, 132mm WIDTH 37mmx37mm MPMG, MG/S MPMGL One Multigrip fits all applications, no left, and right required. Bending slots ensure accurate bends on site. Ideal for fixing Rafters and trusses to top plate. *All dimensions shown are in “mm”. At the time of print, this product is NOT subject to any known warnings and bans found in Building Act 2004. content: 3 NZ MULTIGRIPS DATA SHEET APPLICATION AND SCOPE OF USE Pryda Multigrips can serve a multitude of tie-down needs due to its ability to have either left or right leg fold to suit on-site connection setup. It can also be used as a light duty support cleat when used in PAIRS. Pryda Multigrips are certified when used and installed in accordance with the product datasheet shown connection details. Pryda fasteners approved for the installation form an integral part of the connection and therefore should be used with all Pryda products installation unless otherwise approved by a certified structural Engineer. Only use the product for its intended applications and the selected product material type within the specified environmental condition as outlined in NZS 3604:2011 Table 4.1. (Refer to Durability section for more details). Fastener material type shall match the selected Pryda product. i.e., Galvanised fasteners with galvanised products. Stainless Steel fasteners with stainless steel products. source: NZ Pryda Connectors Tie-downs Design Guide
content: 6 NZ MULTIGRIPS DATA SHEET RIBBON/ DOUBLE TOP PLATE GUIDE Ribbon/double top plates are required to be tied down if they are designed to resist wind uplift. Standard Multigrips or Triple Grips do not have the required length to cover both the top plate and ribbon plate. • If the Ribbon plate is not adequately fixed to the lower top plate, it will not be able to contribute to resisting uplift. • Nail lamination of the ribbon plate to the lower top plate is typically insufficient to resist these loads. • In this example, if the ribbon plate is not sufficiently tied down to the lower top plate it can de-laminate resulting in the trusses lifting off the building. • This example illustrates how the longer leg (MPMGL), can engage both top plates. content: 7 NZ MULTIGRIPS DATA SHEET MPMG, MG/S INSTALLATION FOR TRUSS TIE DOWN CONNECTION TO SUPPORT STEP 1 - • Determine which leg of the Multigrip is required to be bent and do so at a 90° angle. • Ensure the bend line is straight, tight, and firm against both vertical and horizontal timber before fixing into position. STEP 2 - • Fix the Multigrips using Pryda 35 x 3.15mmTimber Connector Nails or Pryda 12G x 35mm Timber Connector screws –painted red head. • Ensure the correct number of nails or screws are used per leg of the Multigrip as per the image above. content:
DIAGRAM DESCRIPTION:
Based on the construction detail from the installation manual for the Multigrips:

1. **Components Shown**: 
   - Multigrip connectors (specifically mentioning left and right leg configurations)
   - Timber support (indicated as a 35 x 135mm member)
   - Connective fixings (notably nails or screws)

2. **Key Measurements or Spacings**: 
   - The timber member dimensions are specified as 35 x 135mm.
   - Fixing requirements specify using 4 nails or screws per connector, but precise spacing is not shown.

3. **Assembly Order or Installation Sequence**: 
   - Step 1 involves determining which leg of the Multigrip to bend (90° angle).
   - The connector is then to be fixed to the timber support using the specified nails or screws.

4. **Critical Details**: 
   - The diagram suggests ensuring that the leg of the Multigrip is straight and aligns both vertically and horizontally before fixing.
   - No specific overlap or minimum clearance details are visible.

This summary captures the vital technical aspects of the assembly as described in the installation manual.

Page context: 7 NZ MULTIGRIPS DATA SHEET MPMG, MG/S INSTALLATION FOR TRUSS TIE DOWN CONNECTION TO SUPPORT STEP 1 - • Determine which leg of the Multigrip is required to be bent and do so at a 90° angle. • Ensure th

chunk_id: NZ Pryda Connectors Tie-downs Design Guide_p45_c0
source: NZ Pryda Connectors Tie-downs Design Guide
content: 8 NZ MULTIGRIPS DATA SHEET MPMG, MG/S INSTALLATION FOR BEAM TO BEAM OR TRUSS TO TRUSS CONNECTION STEP 1 - • Position the supported beam to supporting beam, ensuring both beams are vertically plumb, and all edges are aligned. STEP 2 - • Position a pair of Multigrips at right angles on either side of the support beam. Fix each Multigrip to each timber member with 5 x Pryda 35 x 3.15mm Timber Connector Nails or 3 x Pryda 12G x 35mm Timber Connector Screws - painted red head. STEP 3 - • Repeat the same fixing method to adjacent Multigrip. Note orientation of each Multigrip and connection must be installed in PAIRS. The construction detail shows components related to the installation of a truss tie-down connection. Here’s the analysis:

1. **Components Shown**:
   - **Multigrip**: A metal connector with two legs (left and right).
   - **Framing Member**: Typically a timber truss or beam.
   - **Fixings**: Nails or screws for securing the Multigrip to the wood.

2. **Key Measurements/Spacings**:
   - Specific sizes for the nails or screws are indicated as 2 x 3.5mm for the connector's fastening.

3. **Assembly Order/Installation Sequence**:
   - Step 1: Determine which leg of the Multigrip to bend and bend it at a 90° angle.
   - Install the Multigrip ensuring it is aligned correctly before fixing into position.

4. **Critical Details**:
   - The diagram should specify critical overlaps, such as how far the Multigrip should extend over the framing member.
   - Minimum clearances may be indicated but are not visible from the description. 

This concise breakdown represents the essential technical aspects from the installation manual.

| Where possible, hand nailing with Pryda Timber Connector nails is always preferred, why?                             |

| • Pryda Timber Connector Nails are forged in one piece, unlike clouts that are two pieces soldered together, meaning |

| • Pryda Nails are the correct diameter, ensuring a tight fit in pre-punched holes = a stronger connection.           |
| • Design values and testing have all been conducted using Pryda Timber Connector Nails.                              |
| • Hand hammered nails ensure correct nail positioning and drive depth (not driven too shallow or too deep).          |

source: NZ Pryda Connectors Tie-downs Design Guide
content: PRODUCT DATA SHEET NZ Z and U Nails Versatile and cost-effective tie- down for a variety of connections commonly found on any residential construction. FEATURES AND BENEFITS SIMPLE: The “Z” and “U” Nails are cost-effective means of holding down purlins to rafters, rafter and joists to plates, joists to beams. FAST: Both “Z” and “U” Nails are self-nailing and easy to apply with the 85° angle of the nail to the shaft enabling the nails to draw the timbers to each other. Install using a standard carpenter hammer only. DURABLE: Made from 5mm diameter Zinc Galvanised or Stainless Steel 304. SPECIFICATIONS 5mm Mild Steel Wire to AS2334-1980 or STEEL Stainless Steel 304 THICKNESS 5mm Z Nail (MPZL) Left and (MPZR) Right CORROSION Zinc Galvanise to NZS 3604:2011 Table 4.2 or RESISTANCE Stainless Steel 304 FASTENERS N/A LENGTHS Z Nail 100x40mm, U Nail 100 x 40mm At the time of print, this product is NOT subject to any known warnings and bans found in Building Act 2004. U Nail MPZU *All dimensions shown are in “mm.” Pryda.com.au, Pryda.co.nz DECEMBER 2023 - V1.03 CHECK PRYDA REGION WEBSITE FOR MOST CURRENT VERSION For more information call 1300 657 052 (Australia), 0800 88 22 44 (New Zealand) or email info@pryda.com.au

3. **Assembly Order**: The components should be installed in pairs, with the nails being inserted in the designated load direction.

4. **Critical Details**: 
   - Ensure proper overlap of the timber elements where they join.
   - Observe minimum clearances, particularly the specified 25mm for cross grain and 50mm for end grain to maintain structural integrity.

content:
DIAGRAM DESCRIPTION:
1. **Components Shown:**
   - Pryda Z Nails
   - Timber members (indicated as 'Timber depth')
   - Tie-down connector (Pryda MPZ Nail and Pryda MPZ/2 Nail)
   - Supports for framing members

2. **Key Measurements/Spacings:**
   - Timber depth is noted, particularly where it must be less than 90mm for specific installation guidance.
   - Z nails should be installed in pairs.
   - An angle of approximately 6 degrees is specified for rotation of Z nails when necessary.

3. **Assembly Order/Installation Sequence:**
   - Begin by determining the timber depth.
   - If the timber depth is less than 90mm, rotate each Z nail approximately 6 degrees as shown.
   - Install Z nails in pairs as specified.

4. **Critical Details:**
   - Ensure that each Z nail shall be vertically aligned.
   - Maintain minimum grain clearance for the tie-down connections when installed.
   - Note overlaps or gaps, particularly where specific rotations are required to accommodate timber depths.

This ensures accurate and effective installation of the Pryda Z Nails in accordance with NZ standards.

source: NZ Pryda Bracing Design Guide V1.02
content: GENERAL PRYDA BUILDING GUIDE OVERVIEW Pryda has developed this guide to accommodate New Zealand building practices. It is important that designers, engineers, builders, inspectors and building authorities are familiar with the benefits and critical requirements of the system. Pryda timber connectors, trusses and beams comply with the New Zealand Building Code, Section B1 Structure and B2 Durability, having been designed in accordance with sound and widely accepted engineering principles to comply with NZS3604:2011. The capacities reported in this publication are limit state design capacities and not characteristic strengths thereby allowing direct comparison with design reactions reported in Pryda design software and Pryda design reports. This document supersedes and replaces all the previous publications of Builder's Guide. For further design advice or engineering support regarding the Pryda products discussed in this publication please phone us at 0800 88 22 44 or visit our website - www.pryda.co.nz. The Pryda Design Guide features a Building Consent Documentation Reference for many connection details. This is aimed to encourage designers to align details in the building consent documentation with useful information for easy reference for builders and building officials at the time of inspection. The process is illustrated on the following page. It should be recognised that this is not a requirement, and fabricators may choose to present information in various formats.

chunk_id: NZ Pryda Bracing Design Guide V1.02_p2_c1
source: NZ Pryda Bracing Design Guide V1.02
content: the time of inspection. The process is illustrated on the following page. It should be recognised that this is not a requirement, and fabricators may choose to present information in various formats. The Building Consent Documentation Reference should not be confused with the Pryda product code. The Company Pryda New Zealand is an autonomous division of USA-based Illinois Tool Works Inc. a Fortune 200 diversified manufacturing company with almost 100 years of history. Other successful ITW brands include Paslode, ITW Proline, Ramset and Reid Construction Systems. Pryda also gains valuable benefits in product, fabrication machinery and software development from its association with other ITW software and truss connector suppliers from around the world. Who is Pryda? Pryda was born in Napier, New Zealand in 1964. Pryda has remained an integral part of the building industry in New Zealand for over 50 years, particularly in timber truss and frame solutions with the development of a diverse range of timber connectors and structural brackets. Today Pryda remains a trusted New Zealand brand on building sites, in trade stores and in offices of architects, engineers and designers. Pryda utilises world-class technology to provide a total system package to its licensed truss and frame plants, including fully integrated software and production systems, access to world leading manufacturing equipment and the highest levels of technical support.

Our Philosophy Pryda develops solutions to common construction challenges on the philosophy, "safer, faster, smarter, easier". Pryda’s philosophy is a unique method of looking at the total business needs of its licensed truss and frame fabricators and providing cost effective solutions that not only meet current requirements but also identify and satisfy long term goals . source: NZ Pryda Bracing Design Guide V1.02
content:
DIAGRAM DESCRIPTION:
Based on the provided context of the construction detail/diagram, here’s a concise technical analysis:

1. **Components Shown:**
   - **Concealed Purlin Cleat (NC8 / NPPC8):** Used for connecting purlins to the structure without visible fixings.
   - **Cyclone Strap (MPQHS6, Q9, QHS9):** A component designed for tie-down purposes, providing additional strength in cyclonic conditions.
   - **Wrap Legs under Support Connection:** This detail indicates how the cyclone strap connects to the structural support for enhanced stability.

2. **Key Measurements or Spacings:**
   - Measurements are not explicitly shown in the accompanying text but may include specific dimensions for purlin spacing and strap length based on engineering requirements.

3. **Assembly Order or Installation Sequence:**
   - The installation likely follows this sequence: 
     1. Install the concealed purlin cleat to the structural framing.
     2. Attach the cyclone strap to the required points, ensuring the wrap legs fit under the support.

4. **Critical Details:**
   - Ensure proper **overlaps** of the cyclone strap for effective load distribution.
   - Maintain **gaps** as required to prevent moisture entrapment.
   - Observe **minimum clearances** between components to comply with building standards, particularly for structural integrity during wind events.

This description uses terminology consistent with NZ/AU construction practices and addresses the relevant

source: NZ Pryda Bracing Design Guide V1.02
content: GENERAL When producing an 'As Built' truss layout and final truss detailing for supply, it is expected that a fabricator shall give consideration to any 'Buildable' truss layout that has been consented by a BCA. The fabricator shall consider any structural implications that may result from a different layout to that consented and if any changes are to be made then these shall be communicated to the customer to pass on to their design team for consideration and approval before proceeding with supply. It is not expected that fabricators should have to follow exactly a consented layout, particularly when a competitive party may have provided it. However, a fabricator will have to produce an 'As Built' truss layout as per 2.3.1. This two stage process is reflected in section 7.5 of the guidance document "Guide to applying for a building consent" published by the Department of Building and Housing. Acknowledgement and support for the COP Section 2 – Truss Documentation is also outlined in the publication from DBH Codewords issue 044. Both publications are available online at www.dbh.govt.nz. While it is expected that the documentation is going to be provided to assist a BCA in the consent or CCC process it should be noted that the contractual relationship is between a fabricator and its customer and that the responsibility to provide this information to a BCA rests with the applicant for a building consent. Notes: 1.

The nail-plate manufacturer in turn licenses the fabricator to use specific design software supplied and underwritten by the nail-plate manufacturer. 2. A design lead refers to the architect or draftsperson responsible for the overall design of the building. PRYDA DESIGN GUIDE MARCH 2024 V1.02

content: GENERAL - TIMBER CONNECTORS GUIDE PRODUCER STATEMENT PRYDA TIMBER CONNECTORS August 2024 This Producer Statement is issued by Pryda NZ to cover the use, installation, and durability of Pryda Timber Connectors for both structural application and durability as required by the New Zealand Building Code clauses B1 & B2, respectively. Description The Pryda timber connectors are manufactured from either Z275 or Z600 galvanised coil. Some brackets are also available in hot dipped galvanised or stainless steel for use in certain exposed and covered situations. Application Pryda timber connectors are designed for specific connections of timber to timber, primarily, as well as masonry, concrete, and steel. Please contact Pryda should you require assistance relating to these connectors. Installation Pryda timber connectors should be installed without damage to the finished surfaces. Storage prior to use to be in dry moisture free conditions that would not affect the future durability of the product. Design Capacity As timber grades vary the design capacity is derived using the methods in NZS AS1720.2022 and is mostly dependent on the shear values of the nails, screws, and bolts in timber. Most commonly used Timber Connectors have published limit state design strengths published in our literature.

source: NZ Pryda Bracing Design Guide V1.02
content: 022 and is mostly dependent on the shear values of the nails, screws, and bolts in timber. Most commonly used Timber Connectors have published limit state design strengths published in our literature. Durability The durability of Pryda timber connectors is in accordance with the acceptable solutions contained in Table 4.1 and Table 4.2 of NZS3604:2011 to achieve a 50 year life expectancy for the connectors where applicable. Alternative solutions and direct applications are to be found elsewhere in this publication. 8 41 Poland Rd, Glenfield, 0629 PO Box 100303, North Shore 0757, Auckland. chunk_id: NZ Pryda Bracing Design Guide V1.02_p8_c0
source: NZ Pryda Bracing Design Guide V1.02
content: GENERAL - STRUCTURAL BRACKETS GUIDE PRODUCER STATEMENT STRUCTURAL BRACKETS Pryda Structural Brackets August 2024 This Producer Statement is issued by Pryda NZ to cover the use, installation, and durability of Pryda Structural Brackets for both structural application and durability as required by the New Zealand Building Code clauses B1 & B2, respectively. Description Pryda Structural Brackets are fabricated from flat bar steel. They are mostly available in hot dipped galvanised finish with a selection also available in stainless steel for use as an architectural feature or in certain exposed and covered situations as covered in NZS3604:2011. The zinc coating is applied in accordance with AS/NZS 4680:2006. The remaining Pryda Structural Brackets are finished in electro galvanised. Application Pryda Structural Brackets are designed to connect timber to masonry, concrete, and steel. The brackets are designed for specific connections of timber to other materials. Please contact Pryda technical service should you require assistance with your intended application. Installation The Pryda Structural Brackets should be installed without damage to the finished surfaces. Storage prior to use to be in dry moisture free conditions that would not affect the durability of the product. Characteristic Strength When used with timber, the characteristic strength is derived by the verification method in accordance with the NZBC standard NZS3603:1993.

chunk_id: NZ Pryda Bracing Design Guide V1.02_p8_c1
source: NZ Pryda Bracing Design Guide V1.02
content: ffect the durability of the product. Characteristic Strength When used with timber, the characteristic strength is derived by the verification method in accordance with the NZBC standard NZS3603:1993. The withdrawal strength of the bracket varies with the type of substrate it is installed in, hence the limit state design capacities shall be determined by the design engineer taking into consideration the above point. Durability The durability of the Pryda Structural Brackets is more than the acceptable solutions contained in Table 4.1 of NZS3604:2011 in order to achieve a 50-year life expectancy for the brackets. Pryda Structural Brackets are hot-dipped galvanised to a level equal to or exceeding 500g/m2. Depending on the environmental conditions and exposure to mar ine17 c onditions, the surface of the stainless-steel brackets can be affected by tea staining. However, tea staining does not affect the structural integrity of the fitting. Pryda fasteners approved for the installation form an integral part of the connection and therefore should be used with all Pryda products installation unless otherwise approved by a certified structural Engineer. Only use the product for its intended applications and the selected product material type within the specified environmental condition as outlined in NZS 3604:2011 Table 4.1. (Refer to Durability section for more details). The NZ Bracing Anchor is for fixing timber studs to timber bottom plates to prevent uplift with a capacity of 10.7 kN in accordance with NZS 3604. The NZ Bracing Anchor incorporates a slotted hole for receiving an M12 anchor fixing for the timber bottom plate fixing to a timber or concrete floor in accordance with NZS 3604. chunk_id: NZ Pryda Bracing Design Guide V1.02_p15_diagram
source: NZ Pryda Bracing Design Guide V1.02
content:
DIAGRAM DESCRIPTION:
The diagram appears to detail the installation of Pryda Bracing Anchors for both external and internal wall applications.

1. **Components Shown:**
   - Bracing anchors
   - Framing members (likely timber)
   - Solid plaster finish
   - Cladding (external wall and internal wall noted)
   - Fixings (M12 hardware for anchor installation)

2. **Key Measurements/Spacings:**
   - Minimum clearance for the external wall cladding is indicated.
   - A specified dimension for the external wall cladding width (150mm) is noted.
   - Placement centering details for bracing anchors on framing members must be adhered to.

3. **Assembly Order/Installation Sequence:**
   - The installation of the M12 fixings is indicated to be central to the framing, ensuring proper anchor placement prior to applying cladding.
   - Install external wall cladding first, followed by internal wall bracing after ensuring external detailing is completed.

4. **Critical Details:**
   - Overlaps between components for weatherproofing may be indicated.
   - Minimum clearances and edge distances for fixings are essential for structural integrity, ensuring no part of the fixings is compromised.
   - Any specified gaps between components should also be adhered to for proper functioning of the bracing system and moisture control.

This concise technical summary follows NZ/AU construction terminology relevant to the given installation scenario.

chunk_id: NZ Pryda Bracing Design Guide V1.02_p16_diagram
source: NZ Pryda Bracing Design Guide V1.02
content:
DIAGRAM DESCRIPTION:
This is a construction diagram.

1. **Components Shown:**
   - Timber studs
   - Timber bottom plates
   - Bracing anchor (NZ Bracing Anchor)
   - Fixings (e.g., timber screws)

2. **Key Measurements/Spacings:**
   - The diagram specifies a joint group and load capacities (e.g., JDS: 12.1 kN for wind or wall loads).
   - The minimum distance to the edge of the timber for fixings is indicated as 25mm.

3. **Assembly Order/Installation Sequence:**
   - First, fix the bottom plate to the concrete or foundation.
   - Next, install the timber studs onto the bottom plate using the bracing anchors.
   - Follow with securing the studs with specified fixings.

4. **Critical Details:**
   - Ensure the bracing anchor overlaps the timber stud appropriately.
   - Maintain the 25mm minimum clearances for fixings from the edges to prevent splitting.
   - Properly align bracing for effective load distribution.

chunk_id: NZ Pryda Bracing Design Guide V1.02_p17_c0
source: NZ Pryda Bracing Design Guide V1.02
content: 5 NZ BRACING ANCHOR DATA SHEET INSTALLATION 1.Identify where PBA is to be located from application details. Ensure PBA fits within the wall frame plane. 2.Present PBA to junction of bottom plate and stud ensuring a snug fit to both surfaces referring to relevant floor installation detail shown in application details to ensure correct placement across face of bottom plate. 3.Mark position of bolt or M12 screw using the PBA as a guide and remove PBA. Ensure the selected anchorage into the supporting member has an equivalent or better capacity to PBA. When connecting to a solid beam, ensure the M12 bolt or screw is central to the beam. For concrete slab connection near edge, minimum concrete edge distance shall be maintained. 4.Drill appropriate size hole for bolt or screw with reference to supplier’s data sheet for correct hole size and use of the fastening. 5.Place the PBA into position and fasten home the screw or bolt to a snug fit, ensuring face of PBA is tight against face of stud. 6.Screw 5 x Pryda 12G x 35mm Pryda Timber Connector screws into the stud flange. 7.Re-check the tightness of the M12 screw or anchor bolt. 8.Finally screw 2 x Pryda 12G x 35mm Timber Connector screws into the bottom plate flange. IMPORTANT Pryda CODEMARK certificate CMNZ10028 certifies Pryda Bracing Anchor with use of NZ Pryda Timber Connector Screws. Other fixing methods are outside the scope of the CODEMARK.

chunk_id: NZ Pryda Bracing Design Guide V1.02_p17_c1
source: NZ Pryda Bracing Design Guide V1.02
content: om plate flange. IMPORTANT Pryda CODEMARK certificate CMNZ10028 certifies Pryda Bracing Anchor with use of NZ Pryda Timber Connector Screws. Other fixing methods are outside the scope of the CODEMARK. Installing proprietary anchors correctly, refer to the manufacturer’s mechanical anchoring information guide for specific installation and performance details to ensure that proprietary anchors are installed correctly. When installing anchors, ensure the: • Required slab edge distance is achieved for non-cracked concrete tension– it is possible to blow out the slab edge during installation if the anchor is too close. Anchor capacity may also be reduced due to minimum edge distance. • Correct depth for required embedment depth to achieve capacity rating. • Capacity rating of selected anchor to supporting member has an equivalent or better capacity to PBA. • Hole diameter is suitable for an M12 anchor. • Hole is thoroughly cleaned out after drilling. • Screw is not overtightened – refer to recommended torque settings.

content: N Z STRAPBRACE AND MAXI STRAP DATA SHEET 3 DURABILITY The following table provides an easy guide when selecting a Pryda product corrosion protection finish that will meet and exceeds NZS 3604:2011 Table 4.1. ZONE LOCATION ENVIRONMENT PRODUCT Pryda Zinc Coated All Zones Fully enclosed walls, floors, and roof spaces Closed Products Z275 Vented 7000mm2/m2 or Pryda Stainless Steel All subfloor fastenings LESS Sheltered 304 Products (3) more than 600mm above the ground Vented MORE than Exposed Pryda Stainless Steel 7000mm2/m2 304 Products (3) All subfloor fastenings Zones B and C within 600mm of the Sheltered and Exposed Pryda Stainless Steel 304 Products (3) ground Pryda Stainless Steel Sheltered All other structural 304 Products (3) fixings Pryda Stainless Steel Exposed 304 Products (3) Pryda Stainless Steel Zone D All structural fixings Sheltered and Exposed 304 Products (3) Notes: 1.All Pryda galvanised products comply with NZS3604:2011 Table 4.2. 2.Refer to NZS3604:2011 for all environment definitions. 3.Routine inspection and cleaning using soap and fresh warm water is an integral part of the ongoing care and maintenance of stainless steel to preserve its appearance. STORAGE AND HANDLING Prior to use, the Pryda products shall be stored in a weatherproof environment and protected from moisture. Care must be taken to avoid any damage to the surface of the product protective galvanised coating and profile that may impact the performance.

chunk_id: NZ Pryda Bracing Design Guide V1.02_p20_c1
source: NZ Pryda Bracing Design Guide V1.02
content: a weatherproof environment and protected from moisture. Care must be taken to avoid any damage to the surface of the product protective galvanised coating and profile that may impact the performance. COMPLIES WITH THE FOLLOWING PROVISIONS OF THE NEW ZEALAND BUILDING CODE (NZBC) Clause B1 STRUCTURE: Performance B1.3.1, B1.3.2 and B1.3.4. Loads arising from self-weight, imposed gravity loads arising from use, snow, and wind. (i.e., B1.3.3 (a), (b), (g), and (h)). Only some may apply for a specific use of the component. Clause B2 DURABILITY: Performance B2.3.1 (a) not less than 50 years and B2.3.2. Clause F2 HAZARDOUS BUILDING MATERIALS: Performance F2.3.1. APPLICATION AND SCOPE OF USE Pryda Strap brace is suitable for bracing walls and truss/rafter roof construction (spans up to 12m) in residential buildings. Use Pryda Maxi Strap for larger spans and commercial and industrial buildings. Pryda Tensioners provide a fast, dependable, and simple method of tensioning long lengths of bracing strap. Pryda Strap brace complies with NZS3604:2011 Light Timber Frame Buildings, clause 10.4.2.2 (b) requirements for diagonally opposing pair of continuous metal bracing strips each having a tension capacity of 4kN but is not suitable for use as holding down straps on braced wall panels. Use Pryda Sheet Brace Straps for this application. Pryda Strap brace and Maxi Strap act in tension only. Braces must be applied in pairs as illustrated.

chunk_id: NZ Pryda Bracing Design Guide V1.02_p20_c2
source: NZ Pryda Bracing Design Guide V1.02
content: e as holding down straps on braced wall panels. Use Pryda Sheet Brace Straps for this application. Pryda Strap brace and Maxi Strap act in tension only. Braces must be applied in pairs as illustrated. Holes are pre-punched for Pryda 35x 3.15mm Timber Connector Nails and 6mm tensioner bolts. Pryda Strap Brace and Maxi strap are certified when used and installed in accordance with the product datasheet shown connection details. Pryda fasteners approved for the installation form an integral part of the connection and therefore should be used with all Pryda products installation unless otherwise approved by a certified structural Engineer. Only use the product for its intended applications and the selected product material type within the specified environmental condition as outlined in NZS 3604:2011 Table 4.1. (Refer to Durability section for more details). Fastener material type shall match the selected Pryda product. i.e., Galvanised fasteners with galvanised products. Stainless Steel fasteners with stainless steel products. chunk_id: NZ Pryda Bracing Design Guide V1.02_p21_c0
source: NZ Pryda Bracing Design Guide V1.02
content: N Z STRAPBRACE AND MAXI STRAP DATA SHEET 4 STRAP BRACE MAXI STRAP SB10, SB30 SBI, SBI/15 ROOF AND CEILING BRACING Use in crossed pairs as for wall braces. For residential construction in accordance with NZS3604:2011, secure braces with 6 x Pryda 35 X 3.15mm Timber Connector Nails (12 nails for Maxi Strap) at each end, and 2 nails (after tensioning braces) at truss/ rafter or Purlin crossing. ROOF BRACE DEFINITION A “roof brace” comprises a diagonal pair of Pryda Strap Braces intersecting at 45°, connecting the ridge of the roof to the top plate of the wall with both ends fixed as shown in the diagrams below. A “roof brace” can also be a valley or hip connected continuously. Light Weight Roofs Require ONE “roof brace” in each plane of the roof area per 50m² of plan roof area which also includes any overhangs. Heavy Weight Roofs Require ONE “roof brace” in each plane of the roof area per 25m² of plan roof area which also includes the overhangs. Note: Porches, dormers, and small roof planes of less than 6m² do not require bracing. chunk_id: NZ Pryda Bracing Design Guide V1.02_p21_diagram
source: NZ Pryda Bracing Design Guide V1.02
content:
DIAGRAM DESCRIPTION:
### Construction Detail Analysis

1. **Components Shown:**
   - **Strap Brace:** Utilized for roof and ceiling bracing.
   - **Maxi Strap:** A specific product indicated for enhanced structural support.
   - **Framing members (rafters/trusses):** Indicated as part of the roof structure.
   - **Fixings:** Nails or connectors used to secure the strap braces to the framing elements.

2. **Key Measurements or Spacings:**
   - Specific measurements are not detailed in the image, but common industry practice indicates typical bracing spans typically approximate 600mm to 900mm between fixing points, depending on design specifications.

3. **Assembly Order/Installation Sequence:**
   - Begin with installation of framing members (rafters/trusses).
   - Place strap braces in crossed pairs over the framing, observing correct positioning.
   - Secure the strap braces using specified fixings to attach to the rafters or trusses.

4. **Critical Details:**
   - Ensure that strap braces overlap appropriately where they meet, providing adequate structural integrity.
   - Maintain minimum clearances as may be specified by local building codes or guidelines.
   - Gaps between the braces and the framing should be minimized to avoid compromising bracing effectiveness.

This analysis provides an overview based on typical practices and the elements present in the diagram. For precise dimensions and specifications, refer to the local building standards and the specific product manual.

chunk_id: NZ Pryda Bracing Design Guide V1.02_p22_c0
source: NZ Pryda Bracing Design Guide V1.02
content: N Z STRAPBRACE AND MAXI STRAP DATA SHEET 5 INSTALLATION NOTES 1. The distribution of roof braces should be performed in an even and balanced fashion. 2. For purlins / battens 50mm or deeper, the roof brace shall occupy the plane directly on top of the top chords or rafters. 3. Pryda Strap Brace shall be used for spans up to 12m. For spans over 12m Pryda Maxi brace shall be used. 4. Nail off Pryda Strap Brace at apex end with 5 nails. Layout Pryda Strap Brace at 45° and nail off at heel end with 5 nails. 5. Tension Pryda Strap Brace using Pryda Tensioner before final nailing of one nail per top chord crossing. 2 x Nails to Anchorage Point: each top chord Bend strap brace over side of top chord and fix Pryda Strap brace end with 5 Pryda Timber Connector nails. Three nails to face and 2 nails to top. Nails shall be no Pryda Strap brace closer than 10mm to the edge of the timber. Solid block between trusses/rafter behind each anchorage point. 4. **Critical Details:**
   - The installation specifies that nails should penetrate both the tie plate and timber components.
   - Important for the assembly is the overlap and alignment of the strap braces with the roof framing members to ensure structural integrity.

This analysis is tailored for clarity while retaining essential technical specifics pertinent to NZ/AU construction standards.

content: N Z STRAPBRACE AND MAXI STRAP DATA SHEET 6 BUILD WITH CONFIDENCE Where possible, hand nailing with Pryda Timber Connector nails is always preferred, why? • Pryda Timber Connector Nails are forged in one piece, • Design values and testing have all been conducted unlike clouts that are two pieces soldered together, using Pryda Timber Connector Nails meaning the head can pop off • Hand hammered nails ensure correct nail positioning • Pryda Nails are the correct diameter, ensuring a tight and drive depth (not driven too shallow or too deep) fit in prepunched holes = a stronger connection PRYDA CODEMARK CERTIFICATE CMNZ10029 CERTIFIES PRYDA STRAP BRACE WITH USE OF NZ PRYDA TIMBER CONNECTOR NAILS. OTHER FIXING METHODS ARE OUTSIDE THE SCOPE OF THE CODEMARK.

chunk_id: NZ Pryda Bracing Design Guide V1.02_p23_c1
source: NZ Pryda Bracing Design Guide V1.02
content: holes = a stronger connection PRYDA CODEMARK CERTIFICATE CMNZ10029 CERTIFIES PRYDA STRAP BRACE WITH USE OF NZ PRYDA TIMBER CONNECTOR NAILS. OTHER FIXING METHODS ARE OUTSIDE THE SCOPE OF THE CODEMARK. USING PASLODE MACHINE DRIVEN NAILS Where appropriate, Paslode Machine Driven Nails listed below may be used instead of the specified 35 x 3.15mm Pryda Timber Connector Nails to fix Pryda connectors provided that: • There is one additional nail per connection than specified in the bracing details (e.g., 2 instead of 1, 3 instead of 2, 5 instead of 4 etc.) • Machine driven nails are driven at nail spacings and edge distances similar to the hole pattern, ensuring that these nails are not: - Driven into the holes - Located not closer than 5mm from the edge of a hole - Grouped together - Within 10mm from the edge Screw hardened, electro galvanised Paslode nails that are appropriate include: • Duo-Fast C SHEG 32 x 2.3mm (D40810) • Paslode 32 x 2.5mm (B25110) • Duo-Fast 32 x 2.5mm (D41060) • Pas Coil 32 x 2.5mm SHEG 2 Pack (B25250) • Impulse 32 x 2.5mm SHEG (B40020) Extreme care must be taken when using machine driven nails as the prevailing installation practices tend to inhibit compliance with the above requirements. content: N Z STRAPBRACE AND MAXI STRAP DATA SHEET 7 STRAP BRACE TIPS 1 Larger holes are only for tensioners, do not use them for nails 2 Do not over tension Strap Bracing as this can both reduce the capacity of the unit and bring walls out of plumb 3 Ensure nails are at least 10mm away from timber end or edges to prevent splitting 4 Ensure Strap Brace is tensioned prior to nailing to studs/trusses 5 Keep wall bracing angles within 30° to 60° and roof angles between 30° to 45° or the brace will not be compliant 6 Fix Strap Brace to the Bottom Plate before standing wall Avoid having the center of the opposing brace located over a stud or a nog as this can cause a bump in the 7 plasterboard Contact details Manufacture location New Zealand Legal and trading name of manufacturer Fairfit Engineering Legal and trading name of supplier Pryda New Zealand -a Division of ITW New Zealand Supplier address for service 23-29 Poland Road, Wairau Valley,Auckland, 0627, New Zealand Supplier website Pryda.co.nz Supplier email info@prydaanz.com Supplier phone number 0800 88 22 44 Supplier NZBN 9429039833129 Pryda.com.au, Pryda.co.nz DECEMBER 2023 - V1.02 CHECK PRYDA REGION WEBSITE FOR MOST CURRENT VERSION For more information call 1300 657 052 (Australia), 0800 88 22 44 (New Zealand) or email info@pryda.com.au

STORAGE AND HANDLING Prior to use, the Pryda products shall be stored in a weatherproof environment and protected from moisture. Care must be taken to avoid any damage to the surface of the product protective galvanised coating and profile that may impact the performance.

Only some may apply for a specific use of the component. Clause B2 DURABILITY: Performance B2.3.1 (a) not less than 50 years and B2.3.2. Clause F2 HAZARDOUS BUILDING MATERIALS: Performance F2.3.1. APPLICATION AND SCOPE OF USE Pryda Sheet Brace Straps (SBS) are certified when used and installed in accordance with the product datasheet shown connection details. Pryda fasteners approved for the installation form an integral part of the connection and therefore should be used with all Pryda products installation unless otherwise approved by a certified structural Engineer. Only use the product for its intended applications and the selected product material type within the specified environmental condition as outlined in NZS 3604:2011 Table 4.1. Stainless Steel fasteners with stainless steel products.
